newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Yeltsin to chair key security meeting - Kremlin.
newsitem.headline: Yeltsin to chair key security meeting - Kremlin.

text.p: President Boris Yeltsin, returning slowly to work after a long illness, will chair a meeting of his Security Council in coming weeks to discuss the situation in the volatile north Caucasus, the Kremlin press service said on Monday.
Yeltsin, 66, has held a series of one-on-one meetings since he was taken ill with pneumonia last month but has not headed any committee sessions or atended public meetings.
The next meeting of the Security Council, a policy body grouping senior ministers and the heads of both houses of parliament, is due at the end of February or beginning of March.
Yeltsin was absent from the Kremlin for most of the second half of last year with heart problems and he has looked stiff in recent television appearances.
His absence has fueled opposition charges that Russia is rudderless, although aides insist he is controlling affairs of state and meeting officials at the secluded Gorky-9 residence outside Moscow.
The press service said Yeltsin asked Security Council Secretary Ivan Rybkin to represent him at Wednesday's inauguration of Chechen president Aslan Maskhadov in the regional capital Grozny.
Maskhadov, elected on January 27 with a large majority, says he is seeking full independence for his Caucasus region. He headed the rebel forces during their 21-month war against Russian troops.
Russia pulled its soldiers out of the region last month, but insists that Chechnya is still part of the Russian Federation.
